intro: Acacia nossibiensis, commonly known as the Nossibie acacia, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, multi-branched stems and small, feathery leaves that help reduce water loss in its harsh environment. The plant produces yellow, globular flower heads that bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators such as bees and birds. Its seeds are encased in hard pods, which open to release the seeds when mature. Acacia nossibiensis is well adapted to survive in low-water conditions, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia nossibiensis is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa, particularly in Namibia and Angola. It is commonly found in sandy soils and rocky outcrops, adapting well to the harsh environmental conditions of these areas. This plant thrives in regions with low rainfall and high temperatures, making it a characteristic species of the Namib Desert and surrounding areas. It plays an important ecological role by providing shelter and food for local wildlife. Due to its resilience, it is often used in reforestation projects in degraded landscapes.

It is commonly found in regions of Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory and Western Australia. This plant is often used for erosion control due to its extensive root system and ability to stabilize soil.
